The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.p: THE BATTAILE ON HOPTON-HEATH IN STAFFORDSHIRE, Betweene His MAJESTIES Forces under the Right Honourable the Earle of NORTHAMPTON, and tho≈øe of the Rebels, March 19.
Together with A Letter from the Lord COMPTON now Earle of NORTHAMPTON.

div.head: THE BATTAILE ON HOPTON-HEATH.
div.p: IT is too manife≈øt what poore ≈øhifts the Authors of this re ‚Ä¢ llion have u≈øed to bring about their de≈øigns: among whom none have beene more bu≈øie then Sir William Brereton and Sir John Gell, two that (one would think) have con≈øpired together to be beaten as often as they unite their mutuall forces. Witne≈ø≈øe A≈øhby de-la-zouch and other places where they shamefully have beene wor≈øted by that noble couragious Colonell Ha≈øtings. Though I mu≈øt tell you both Brereton and Gell for their per≈øonall valour are as notorious Cowards as any in the ≈øaw-pit. I confe≈ø≈øe indeed, Gell dare fight, provided his enemy have beene ≈øeven yeares dead; his valour having lately shewed it ≈øelfe again≈øt the Coffins and Monuments of ≈øome dead men, who≈øe living fac ‚Ä¢ s he dur≈øt not looke upon, as if his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe lay (like that devil's in the G ‚Ä¢ ≈øpell) among the Tombes and Sepulchres. And Brereton is as valiant as hee, if lying downe in a ditch, ≈øtanding behind a hayricke, or riding a full mile from the field, may goe for valour, of which three performances his owne Souldiers confe≈ø≈øe him guilty. And yet the≈øe two Champions (to shew they are perfect Cowards) are alwayes rai≈øing quarrels, and ≈øeducing His Maje≈øties ≈øubjects to kill one another; As in many other, ≈øo in this battaile on Hopton Heath, an impartiall Relation whereof you here have by an expre≈ø≈øe from farre better hands.

body.p:
Upon Friday la≈øt having intelligence of the Enemies intentions to approach hither, we marched towards the way wee conceived they would come, and having notice of about two hundred of them quartered in a Towne called Heywood in Stafford≈øhire neare to our pa≈ø≈øe, we fell upon them, and after a ≈øhort skirmi≈øh beat them from their hold, took and killed above the one halfe of them, the re≈øt e≈øcaping by by-wayes ≈øo that we could not follow them, onely quartered there that night Sunday being at Stafford, about twelve of the clock we had intelligence of Sr W. Brereton and Sr John Gells being met with all their forces, being about 3000 Hor≈øe and Foote, placed upon a Heath called Hopton Heath neare a Towne called We≈øton ≈øome two miles from Stafford. We drew out our Hor≈øe and Dragooners being about 900. And the Heath ≈øeeming faire re≈øolved to charge them, the breadth of it being more then Musket≈øhot from inclo≈øure on each ≈øide. As we advanced we di≈øcovered Musketeers placed within a walled Clo≈øe, and ≈øome Musketeers and drakes in hedges on our right wing. Again≈øt which we ≈øent ≈øome of our Musketeers but tho≈øe being too few to beat them, by order of coun≈øell we advanced with our whole body of Hor≈øe (leaving onely a Re≈øerve) towards their body, and upon our advancing their Musketeers ran from the hedges, we chargeing their body their Hor≈øe pre≈øently ran, and we forced them to quit their Cannon. But our men following the Execution beyond command, and our Musketeers not comming up, they got ≈øome of their Cannon againe, yet we brought off 8 peeces. And then rallying up our hor≈øe againe as ≈øoone as we could, we charged ≈øome other Hor≈øe which they had neare their Foot, which pre≈øently retreated and ran, and then
Sir Thomas Byron at the head of the Princes Regiment chargeing their Foot broke in among them, but they having ≈øome Troops of Hor≈øe neare their Foot, fell upon him, and then he received his hurts, bleeding ≈øo that he was not able to ≈øtay in the field. But by rea≈øon of the night and our Hor≈øes being weary we ≈øtood about a Musket-≈øhot from them, and after a time our men being weary, we drew ≈øomewhat further off, keeping ≈øtrong parties nearer them. The next morning by breake of day we made ready to fall on againe, but finding no Enemy, we then under≈øtood that they had marched away in the night about an hour after our parting with them, there we found carriages, with Ammunition and other things, & the fore carriages of their Cannon, which makes us beleeve they have throwne the re≈øt of their Cannon into ≈øome pooles thereabouts. In this fight (and in that former skirmi≈øh on Friday) we took and killed above 300, and wounded at the lea≈øt 500 more (for our Hor≈øe charged their Foot which occa≈øioned ≈øo many wounded) as their owne men confe≈ø≈øe whom ≈øince we tooke pri≈øoners. We have taken above 300 of their Hor≈øe, 8 peeces of Cannon, with a great deal of other Ammunition. Gell is certainly hurt but not killed, yet they ≈øay he was hurt by chance by one of their owne ≈øouldiers as they went away in the night, and we are apt enough to beleeve it, for he is not too forward to come into danger.

But now we mu≈øt from the ≈øadne≈ø≈øe of our ≈øoules acquaint you with the great lo≈ø≈øe both His Maje≈øtie and the whole kingdome have ≈øu≈øteined in this action by the death of a mo≈øt Loyall and hardly to be equalled Subject, the mo≈øt noble and mo≈øt valiant Earle of Northampton, who upon the fir≈øt charge with out hor≈øe, being engaged upon Execution neare their foot, his hor≈øe was ≈øhot, ≈øo that he was con≈øtrained to alight, and being encompa≈ø≈øed with enemies he fought on foot a long time, killing (as they them≈øelves confe≈ø≈øe) a Colonel of foot, and ≈øtriking another
Captain into the bre≈øt with his Poleax, be≈øides other common ≈øouldiers whom he wounded and ≈ølew, untill ≈øuch time as he was overborne by multitudes, and then being knockt downe with a musket and grievou≈øly wounded, and his head-peece taken off, was offered quarter (as they ≈øay) but he an≈øwered that he ≈øcorned to take quarter from ≈øuch ba≈øe rogues & Rebels as they were; and ≈øo fought it out a long while after, till ≈øuch time as he was ≈øhine by a blow with a halbert, on the hinder part of his head, receiving at the ≈øame time another deep wound in his face. Which done, they hurried him away ≈øo as we all thought he had been taken pri≈øoner‚ñ™ for we could not find his body.

The ≈øadne≈ø≈øe of this accident would not have left our greate≈øt Victory without mi≈øery, but yet the grearne≈ø≈øe of his example cannot but make all tho≈øe that are de≈øirous of honour to follow him in his ≈øteps; though none can come nearer him then his brave ≈øonnes, and e≈øpecially the Lord Compton: In whom we find much gallantry and valour in this la≈øt action (wherein he received a ≈øhot in the legge, but no waies dangerous, and his hor≈øe al≈øo ≈øhot under him.) So that ≈øhould we not ≈øay, that there is none more fitting, or de≈øerving to ≈øerve HIS MAJESTY and the Kingdome in tho≈øe Commands, and Honourable imployments which his Father enjoyed, then this young Lord, wee ≈øhould both wrong his Lord≈øhip, and our owne judgements. Wee are a≈ø≈øured he will be found to be the inheritor of his Fathers Loyalty and Vertues, and endeavour by ≈øerving His Maie≈øty, to revenge his fathers death, and equall him in glorious actions. In which we ≈øhall be ready to follow him, and are preparing for that purpo≈øe. We had 25 ≈ølayne, the cheife whereof were Captaine Harvy of my Lords own Regiment, Captain Baker lately a ≈øcholler in Oxford, En≈øigne Bowyer, Captain Middleton of Colonel Ha≈øtings Regiment, Leiutenant Greene, Coronet Billing and Coronet Hall, who all carried them≈øelves as gallantly as men could do. There were about ≈øome twenty hurt, the mo≈øt whereof were Officers; as Sir Thomas
Byron, Colonell Stanhope, Colonell Wag≈øtaffe, Captaine Knotsford, Captaine Richard Bagot, Captaine Harvey Bagot, Captaine John Clarke, Captaine Thomas Harwood, Ma≈øter Spencer Lucy, Lieutenant Leving, Coronet Mettham, Coronet Wa≈øhington, and Ma≈øter Lanca≈øter, be≈øides my Lord Compton's ≈øhot in the legge, not a man of the≈øe but expre≈ø≈øed admirable valour, the ≈øervice for the time being very hot, and the enemies being above three times our number, &c.

There can be little added to this expre≈ø≈øe Relation, wherein though it plea≈øed God ≈øo to defeat the Rebels, yet our lo≈ø≈øe is invaluable in the death of this noble Earle; who as he was early up (being one of the fir≈øt defenders of this righteous cau≈øe) ≈øo he continued at ≈øuch a height of courage and magnanimity, as drew all good mens eyes on his honourable actions. Whether the Rebels offered him quarter, or whether he refu≈øed it when it was offered, is not certaine, for we have it onely from them≈øelves, who no doubt will make their be≈øt excu≈øe for murthering ≈øo incomparable a Lord. Nor is it improbable that he ≈øcorned their quarter, preferring a pre≈øent honourable death before that vile, wretched, unprofitable captivity, whereof he was a≈ø≈øured, were he once their pri≈øoner. For as he ≈øpent his noble endeavours in defence of his King and Country while he lived, ≈øo he valued not his life when it would be ≈øerviceable to none but Rebels. He hath beene often heard to ≈øay, that, If he out-lived the≈øe Warres, he was certaine never to have ≈øo noble a death. And had we wholly lo≈øt him, it would have fill'd us with too much ≈øorrow, but that we have ≈øuch excellent Copies of him in his rare ≈øonnes, and chiefly in the gallant young Earle him≈øelfe, who hath ≈øo much of the father in him, that he only wants time and opportunity to make him more like him. And this you will partly gather by this en≈øuing Letter which my Lord writ with his own hand to the noble Counte≈ø≈øe his Mother, two dayes after his Fathers death.

ON Sunday la≈øt we got the day of the Rebels, but our lo≈ø≈øe (e≈øpecially your Honours and mine) is not to be expre≈ø≈øed. For though it be a generall lo≈ø≈øe to the Kingdome, yet it toucheth us neare≈øt. But Madam, Ca≈øualties in this world will happen, & in ≈øuch a cau≈øe who would not have ventured both life and fortune? pray'e Madam, let this be your comfort, that it was impo≈ø≈øible for any to do braver then he did, as appeares by their owne Relation. I ≈øent a Trumpeter to know what was become of my Father, hee brought me a Letter from Sir Iohn Gell and Sir VVilliam Brereton, a≈ø≈øuring mee of my Fathers death, making ≈øtrange demand for his body, ≈øuch as were never before heard of in any warre, as all their Ammunition, Pri≈øoners, and Cannon which we had taken. I ≈øent them word backe, that their demands were unrea≈øonable, and again≈øt the Lawes of Armes, but de≈øired them to give free pa≈ø≈øage to ≈øome Chirurgeons to embalme him, or to let their Chirurgeons doe it, and I would ≈øatisfy them for their paines. their la≈øt An≈øwer I have ≈øent in Philip VVilloughby's Letter which is, that they will neither ≈øend the body nor ≈øuffer our Chirurgeons to come to embalme it, but will ≈øee their owne Chirurgeons doe it. Their Relation was, that He was a≈ø≈øaulted by many together, and with
his owne hand killed the Colonel and others al≈øo, but was unhor≈øed by the multitude, his hor≈øe being ≈øhot: But his Armour was ≈øo good that they could not hurt him, till he was downe, and had undone his head-peece.

'Pray'e Madam, be comforted, and think no man could more honourably have ended this life (fighting for his Religion, his King, and his Country) to be partaker of heavenly joies. We mu≈øt certainely follow him, but can hardly hope for ≈øo brave a death. Thus humbly craving your ble≈øsing, I ≈øhall remaine till death

div.p: Let the Reader now judge, if the genius and ≈øpirit of the Father be not eminent in the ≈øonne, and whether that hand that wrote this Letter doth not promi≈øe as great hopes for the good of this Kingdome as any whom≈øoever of his age and quality. Next you may ≈øee the Barbarou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the≈øe Rebels towards the Corps of the dead, who as they have made ≈øale of their Allegiance and Loyalty, ≈øo now have ≈øhaken hands with all common hone≈øty, practi≈øing tho≈øe inhumanities the very Turks ≈øcorne to de≈øcend to; For the Mahometans if they kills Commander that is an Enemy, doe not only embalme the corps, but give it ≈øafe convoy to the enemies quarters, that the freinds of the dead may give it buriall, as the noble Earle of Craford and others that have beene in the warres betwixt the Polonian and the Turke,can te≈øtify to be true. And doubtle≈ø≈øe if the Turkes knew what breach of faith given, what robbing, ≈øtripping naked, nay murther (after Armes delivered up by compo≈øition) hath beene committed on His Maje≈øties ≈øouldiers, it would further harden them again≈øt Chri≈øtianity; unle≈ø≈øe they con≈øider that the≈øe things were done not as they are Chri≈øtians, but as the wor≈øt of Rebels. And let them not for ≈øhame object, that wee loo≈øe men of eminencie, but they do not, le≈øt wee tell the world the rea≈øon. For as the Commanders of the≈øe rebellious Forces are made up of all Religions and Trades, ≈øo tho≈øe few men of quality that are on their ≈øide, are driven by their guilt into ditches, and ≈øaw-pits, any whither out of the reach of danger, as not daring to leave the world with all their ≈øinnes about them. Therefore were it any cau≈øe under Heaven but this, that is, were not Religion, Honour, Learning, Lawes, Nobility, Gentry, Hone≈øty, and all at ≈øtake, the≈øe Noble Lords and Gentlemen would not make their bloud ≈øo cheape, as to ≈øpend it on ≈øuch unworthy enemies, who as they have endeavoured to murther both King and Queene, ≈øo labour the ruine of every Engli≈øh Gentleman.
